bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Lunsford D. Fricks, December 24, 1921

div1.p: [Carter] does not see the need to write another systematic treatise on malaria control. He suggests two different alternatives.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Lunsford D. Fricks, December 24, 1921
div1.opener:
N. M. C.
Fricks
(Proposed publication.
on Malaria)
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
December 24, 1921.
Dear Doctor Fricks:
div1.p:
I have looked over “Milk.” I have not seen Sherry. I do not
think it advisable for the Malaria Division to attempt to write a
book on Malaria of the same scope as “Milk.”

(1) The status of malaria at present is quite different from
that of milk when the book in question was written (1908-09).

At that time, as far as I can judge by reading “Milk,” there
was no fairly complete, systematic publication treating of milk.
There was, indeed, a great mass of information, much of it valuable,
in monographs-each on some phase, or phases, of the question.
Bringing this data together--coordinating and digesting it and mak-
ing it available in one publication was very desireable.

This is not true of malaria. First consider its medical as-
pect: I do not know if there has been enough added--on the purely
medical aspect--since the treatises of Craig and Deaderick to re-
quire a new book. Even if these are a little out of date, there are
recent articles in several systems of medicine: In Woods (von Ez-
dorf) about 1916: Tyce's (Bass I think) and the Nelson “Loose-Leaf,”
both published since the war and the latter claiming to be kept up
to date. James' “Malaria at Home and Abroad” is just out and “The
Practice of Medicine in the Tropics” (Oxford Press) is now coming
out with articles on malaria by Christophers: James: Parsons and
John Thomson, each writing separately. Why they didn't get Stephens
2
Stephens
too and make a complete job of it, I don't know.

There seems then to be no lack of literature in book form on
on malaria in its medical aspect. Absolutely up to date and a fair
part of it American.

(2) I doubt if any of our men could write a better or more au-
thoritative book on malaria than some of those available.

Frankly the, I think that for the Medical Aspect of Malaria,
(1) there is no need for a better book than is now available and (2) if
there is, we can't undertake to furnish it. We had best let that as-
pect of malaria alone.

For the sanitary aspect conditions are somewhat different. There
is really no book to be considered here but Ross' “Prevention of Mal-
aria.” Unquestionably we can add to this--it dates from 1910 or '11--
otherwise I doubt if we can improve on it. Certainly any systematic,
basic treatise on this subject must duplicate much of Ross' material
and the bulk of it is admirably presented.

I think then that there is little need of another systematic
treatise on Malaria Control, basic and complete, as Milk was when
written.

The following might be undertaken as an alternative, although I
am not so sure that you are fixed just now to do it to the best ad-
vantage:

We have, as have other men, added something to the knowledge of
malaria control, since the publication of Ross' book, and this knowl-
edge is not in convenient form.
You might make up a small book composed of

(A) excerpts from published American work (1) from such Service: re-
prints: bulletins etc. as show things of value for the U. S.:
U. S.:

(2) similar excerpts from other U. S. workers (this is almost con-
fined to Bass, but Van Dine: King and Freeborn also come in and possi-
bly Thibault and Krauss. I don't think Dock has added anything re-
cently, but am not sure.)

(B) Similar excerpts from foreign sources of such things as seem
both valuable and applicable to American conditions.

Assuming all necessary knowledge of malaria for the purpose, get
out a small book--like a hand-book--on Malaria Control for U. S. use.
This could, I think, be made useful. It could give (a) an exposition
of the cost of malaria in the U. S.: (b) the principles of control,
with the general methods of applying it: (c) application of these dif-
ferent methods with examples giving results: costs: gains etc. with
such discussion as to the indications for the use of the different ones
as may be advisable. (d) Details of the applications of each general
method--as under “Drainage” the use of dynamite: ditching machines: ver-
tical drainage etc.: similarly for Oiling: Larvecide: Fish etc. These
last three, indeed, really come under one general method--fish are as
much a larvecide as arsenic.

This would be preferably by papers by different field men and
would be the bulk of the book.

Get out 1. as soon as convenient--it involves the less work of
the two. Then 11. as we can. Have both bound on the “loose-leaf” sys-
tem so that an addition to each can, and will be, made every year (or
6 months?). Thus the pamphlet would stay more or less up to date.
What do you think of it?

Unless something be provided for progress I would be in favor of
favor of
4
postponing the work a few years. We haven't completed the study of
impounded waters: of rice-fields: malaria: of the efficacy of A. punc-
tipennis as a vector in nature: of the the differential breeding habits
of this species as compared with quads. and crucians: of the effect of
shade on breeding and a number of others. On all we have data--picked
up in surveys made for other purposes--but none are really complete.
Indeed, one would like to have a full year--or longer--trial of Paris
green, which promises to be the most important addition to our arma-
mentarium since the introduction of oil. The same is true of fish--as
you are now using them--probably more valuable than either oil or ar-
senic--and a longer observation seems advisable.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General (On Waiting Orders).
